G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 231, §§ 2 & 1, as the amount in controversy is under $50,000 and the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 2 & 1.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 231, §§ 2 & 1, as the amount in controversy is under $50,000 and the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease under Massachusetts law.  See Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes an implied obligation that a lessor refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, and it discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not state that such a covenant is implied in every residential lease as a matter of Massachusetts law. The lease here is for dental offices in an apartment building (a commercial use), and the court’s reasoning is framed generally in terms of grants and leases, not specifically or categorically about all residential leases. Thus, citing Winchester for the specific proposition that quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease overstates what the case holds.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The same act may be a breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment and also a wrong causing injury to the tenant…”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease under Massachusetts law.  See Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33 (1929); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states, in its discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law background, that every tenancy carries an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. That is a clear recognition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in all residential tenancies under Massachusetts law, consistent with the proposition and citing Winchester v. O’Brien.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Doe v. Superintendent of Schools of Worc.raw_text: Doe v. Superintendent of Schools of Worcester, 421 Mass. 117 (1995)
Doe v. Superintendent of Schools of Worc.proposition: Defendant, by failing to take reasonable steps to stop ongoing and unreasonable disturbances by another tenant on the property under his control, indirectly interfered with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment.  See Doe v. Superintendent of Schools of Worcester, 421 Mass. 117 (1995); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Doe v. Superintendent of Schools of Worc.support_reasoning: This case concerns a student’s expulsion from school under a weapons policy and analyzes statutory authority, discretion, constitutional due process, and vagueness. It does not involve landlord-tenant relations, quiet enjoyment, or a defendant’s failure to control another tenant’s disturbances. The proposition about indirect interference with quiet enjoyment by not stopping another tenant’s disturbances is therefore not addressed or supported by this opinion.
Doe v. Superintendent of Schools of Worc.relevant_excerpt: This opinion contains no discussion of landlords, tenants, or quiet enjoyment; it addresses only school disciplinary authority under G. L. c. 71, § 37H and related constitutional issues. Accordingly, there is no excerpt relevant to the claimed landlord-tenant proposition.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when, through inaction or indifference, he permits disturbing conduct by tenants or others under his control that substantially interferes with another tenant’s use of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment (and thus constructively evict) where, even without intent, the substantial interference with the tenant’s use is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the offending conduct. The court emphasizes landlord responsibility for conditions created and then allowed to persist through inaction, rejecting any strict malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction, which matches the proposition’s description of inaction or indifference toward disturbing conduct under the landlord’s control.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. … Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act after repeated complaints constitutes unreasonable and substantial interference in violation of the covenant.  See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct based on notice and a failure to act reasonably, and it cites Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority for the proposition that a landlord who "stood idle, despite continued requests and complaints" may violate § 14. Although the core issue is lead paint, the court’s description of quiet enjoyment liability clearly endorses the principle that failure to respond to repeated complaints and to take available corrective measures can constitute unreasonable and substantial interference. Thus, the case supports using § 14 where a landlord fails to act after repeated complaints.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises. See, e.g., Cruz, supra at 790; Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285-288 (1994)… In Doe… we vacated the summary judgment… because “the record suggests that the [landlord] stood idle, despite continued requests and complaints by the tenants… and stood idle when there were certain [corrective] measures that it could have taken relatively easily.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act after repeated complaints constitutes unreasonable and substantial interference in violation of the covenant.  See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a landlord’s failure to act after repeated complaints as constituting unreasonable and substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. In Haddad v. Gonzalez, the court discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and Chapter 93A, but it does not analyze or set out the standard for ‘unreasonable and substantial interference’ under the covenant of quiet enjoyment in any detail. The opinion affirms judgment on a quiet enjoyment counterclaim but focuses its legal analysis elsewhere, so it is not clear authority for the specific proposition stated.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability), and attorneys' fees and costs. … Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The noise disturbances were continuous, foreseeable, and within Defendant’s ability to address, making his inaction legally attributable to him.  See Winchester v. O’Brien, supra; Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case involves a landlord’s failure to provide heat and addresses breach of quiet enjoyment and G.L. c. 186, § 14, not noise disturbances. Its holding focuses on the landlord’s liability being based on conduct and the natural and probable consequences of that conduct, rejecting financial inability as a defense. It does not discuss continuous or foreseeable noise, disturbances caused by third parties, or the landlord’s ability to abate such noise, so it does not support the specific proposition about noise disturbances being legally attributable to the defendant’s inaction.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass. 464 (1955)
Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct and omissions have deprived Plaintiff of “peaceful and quiet enjoyment” guaranteed by the lease and Massachusetts law.  See Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass. 464 (1955); Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1984).
Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: This case concerns tort liability for property damage caused by blasting on adjacent land and distinguishes between strict liability for direct physical invasion (rocks/debris) and the need to prove negligence for damage from concussion or vibration. It does not involve a landlord–tenant relationship, lease covenants, or the concept of ‘peaceful and quiet enjoyment’ under Massachusetts landlord–tenant law. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a defendant’s conduct deprived a tenant of quiet enjoyment guaranteed by a lease or statute.
Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Under our decisions one carrying on blasting operations is liable without proof of negligence for all direct injuries to the property of another, as where stones or debris are cast upon it; but in the absence of negligence there is no liability for consequential harm such as is caused by concussion or vibration.”

Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1.raw_text: Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1984)
Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1.proposition: Defendant’s conduct and omissions have deprived Plaintiff of “peaceful and quiet enjoyment” guaranteed by the lease and Massachusetts law.  See Coughlan v. Grande & Son, Inc., 332 Mass. 464 (1955); Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1984).
Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1.support_reasoning: Haber v. Cohen concerns the effect of the federal bankruptcy automatic stay on a Massachusetts separate support judgment. It does not discuss a tenant’s (or spouse’s) right to peaceful and quiet enjoyment under a lease or Massachusetts landlord-tenant law, nor does it analyze interference with quiet enjoyment as a legal theory. The case is about bankruptcy procedure and the validity of a support judgment entered post‑petition, so it does not provide authority for the proposition cited.
Haber v. Cohen, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 627 (1.relevant_excerpt: It thus becomes apparent under our construction of § 362 that the final judgment in this case was entered in violation of the automatic stay, gave the wife no collectible debt of maintenance or support, and is void. ... As a consequence, we conclude that we must vacate the judgment in its entirety and remand the case to the Probate Court for further proceedings if permission is received from the Bankruptcy Court to proceed.
